platform_rent_extraction.platform_or_intermediary: Hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) - Partner credit degradation mechanism
platform_rent_extraction.rent_extraction_mechanism: SYSTEMATIC REDUCTION of partner program benefits over time as hyperscalers prioritize direct customer relationships over channel partners. Mechanism: Hyperscaler partner programs historically provided 20-25% discounts off list pricing to qualified MSP partners (volume tiers, competency certifications, co-sell commitments). Stage 3.4 silent price erosion analysis estimates current partner credits declined to 10-15%, representing 6-13% INPUT COST INCREASE on Public Cloud infrastructure over 5-year period. Extraction occurs through PROGRAM TERMS CHANGES presented as 'partner program evolution': (1) TIER REQUIREMENTS tightening (higher revenue thresholds for same discount levels, more certifications required, co-sell quotas increasing), makes maintaining historical discount levels increasingly difficult, (2) CREDIT TYPES shifting from upfront discounts to back-end rebates (Rackspace must fund full cost initially, receive portion back months later = working capital burden + uncertainty), (3) INCENTIVE STRUCTURE changing from infrastructure discounts to co-sell incentives (rewards hyperscaler-driven deals not partner-driven deals, shifts partner role from independent to hyperscaler sales extension), (4) QUALIFICATION CRITERIA adding customer success metrics tied to hyperscaler product adoption (partners must drive customers to use more hyperscaler services to maintain credits, aligns partner incentives with hyperscaler expansion not customer value). STRATEGIC PURPOSE: Hyperscalers systematically devalue MSP partner channel while maintaining appearance of partnership (can't abruptly terminate relationships without channel disruption), gradual credit erosion FORCES partners to accept deteriorating economics or exit voluntarily (hyperscalers achieve disintermediation without explicitly cutting off partners). MSPs who remain become LOWER-MARGIN operators increasingly dependent on hyperscaler terms (exactly observed pattern for Rackspace: 3.1% EBITDA, 89.6% value to hyperscalers per Stage 3.1).
platform_rent_extraction.who_absorbs_cost: RACKSPACE absorbs cost entirely. Cannot pass through to customers because: (1) Customers don't see partner credit structure (transparent pricing to customers vs wholesale costs to Rackspace), credit reduction = input cost increase that must be absorbed or passed through as price increase, (2) Stage 3.4 pricing analysis shows Rackspace has ZERO pricing power (cannot increase prices without triggering churn, Email 706% proves), cannot pass through cost increases, (3) Competitive pressure from hyperscaler-direct prevents pricing increases (if Rackspace increases prices, customers compare to hyperscaler direct pricing which doesn't increase = Rackspace becomes uncompetitive). Result: 6-13% input cost increase over 5 years FULLY ABSORBED by Rackspace = margin compression of 30-65% of Public Cloud gross margin (Stage 3.4 quantification). If Public Cloud historically had 20-25% gross margins (estimate), declined to 13-17% currently from credit erosion alone, before other costs. Segment EBITDA margins estimated at 3-5% (Stage 3.4), further partner credit degradation pushes to ZERO or NEGATIVE within 2-3 years if trend continues.
platform_rent_extraction.long_term_effect: TERMINAL MARGIN COMPRESSION creating PUBLIC CLOUD SEGMENT UNVIABILITY. Hyperscaler partner credit erosion is SYSTEMATIC not episodic (ongoing program changes, not one-time event) and IRREVERSIBLE (credits decline over time, never increase = one-way ratchet). Long-term trajectory: Partner credits decline from 20-25% (2018-2020 historical estimate) → 10-15% (2024 current) → 5-10% (2027-2028 projection) → 0-5% (2030+ endpoint) as hyperscalers complete channel disintermediation. Each 5% credit reduction eliminates approximately 25-30% of Public Cloud segment gross margin (given thin margins). Endpoint economics: Public Cloud segment operates at ZERO or NEGATIVE margins when partner credits approach zero, Rackspace becomes PASS-THROUGH entity (infrastructure costs ~90-95% of revenue, own costs 5-10% = break-even or loss at operational level). At zero/negative margins, Public Cloud segment is ECONOMICALLY WORTHLESS (generates revenue but no profit) or VALUE-DESTRUCTIVE (subsidized by other segments). STRATEGIC OUTCOME: Hyperscalers successfully COMMODITIZE MSP partner channel through systematic rent extraction, MSPs become SALES AND SUPPORT AGENTS for hyperscalers (assume customer-facing costs, churn risk, support burden) while hyperscalers capture economics. Rackspace faces: (1) CONTINUE operating Public Cloud at declining margins until unprofitable (harvest mode, 3-5 years remaining), (2) EXIT Public Cloud segment voluntarily (admit business model failed), or (3) TRANSFORM to hyperscaler sales agent (accept role as customer acquisition channel for hyperscalers without attempting to capture value). All paths lead to PUBLIC CLOUD SEGMENT ELIMINATION or STRATEGIC IRRELEVANCE.
evidence_sources: Stage 3.4: Silent price erosion analysis estimating hyperscaler partner credits declined from 20-25% to 10-15%, causing 6-13% input cost increase and 30-65% gross margin compression
Stage 3.1: Value capture analysis showing hyperscalers capture 89.6% of customer value vs Rackspace 10.4%, indicates systematic value extraction favoring platforms
Stage 3.2: Hyperscaler-direct competition identified as primary threat, strategic priority for hyperscalers is disintermediation of MSP partners
Industry pattern: Cloud platform providers (AWS, Azure, Google) systematically reducing partner program benefits 2018-2025 as direct go-to-market matures

platform_rent_extraction.rent_extraction_mechanism: UNILATERAL PRICE INCREASES exploiting technical lock-in of installed base. Stage 2.5 FACT: Broadcom acquired VMware 2023, immediately increased pricing 200-300% (2-3x previous levels), resulting in $100-210M annual cost increase to Rackspace. Mechanism: VMware software embedded in customer infrastructure creates TECHNICAL LOCK-IN (workloads, automation, integrations cannot easily migrate, switching costs $2-10M and 12-24 months per Stage 2.4), Broadcom exploits lock-in through PRICING MONOPOLY (no competitive alternatives at comparable migration costs). Extraction occurs through: (1) MAINTENANCE INCREASES - annual maintenance fees increased 200-300% (from typical 18-22% of license value to 40-60%+), customers who purchased perpetual licenses historically now face MANDATORY SUBSCRIPTION transitions at dramatically higher costs, (2) BUNDLING REQUIREMENTS - Broadcom forces customers to purchase broader product bundles (VMware Cloud Foundation vs individual products) at higher price points, cannot purchase only needed components, (3) MINIMUM COMMITMENTS - enterprise license agreements require minimum spending levels that increase annually, prevents customers from reducing VMware footprint even as workloads migrate to cloud, (4) RETROACTIVE POLICY CHANGES - Broadcom changed support policies retroactively (true-up audits, CPU core counting methodologies, entitled vs consumed licensing) that increase costs without customer recourse. STRATEGIC PURPOSE: Broadcom acquisition was FINANCIAL ENGINEERING (PE-style value extraction from acquired software assets), maximize short-term cash extraction from locked-in installed base regardless of customer attrition (deliberately trading long-term customer relationships for immediate cash flow), classic 'squeeze the lemon' strategy. Broadcom KNOWS customers will eventually leave (migrate to cloud-native, alternative platforms over 3-7 years) but extracts MAXIMUM value during exit period.
platform_rent_extraction.who_absorbs_cost: SHARED ABSORPTION between Rackspace and end customers, both harmed: (1) RACKSPACE absorption: Stage 3.4 analysis estimates Rackspace absorbing 30-50% of VMware cost increase ($30-105M annually) to prevent customer churn, this portion DIRECTLY destroys Rackspace margins (Private Cloud segment margins compressed from estimated 5-8% EBITDA to 0-3%, potentially negative), (2) CUSTOMER absorption: Customers facing 30-70% price increases at renewals (Rackspace attempting to pass through 50-70% of cost increase), Stage 3.3 identifies $90-150M customer churn over 3 years as customers REJECT pricing (13% of Private Cloud base chooses to OVERCOME $2-10M switching costs vs accept recurring price increases), (3) MARKET absorption: VMware price shock ACCELERATES Private Cloud to Public Cloud migration (customers decide if being forced to spend $2-10M on migration anyway, prefer to migrate TO PUBLIC CLOUD vs TO ALTERNATIVE HYPERVISOR, moves workloads from Rackspace Private Cloud to hyperscaler-direct Public Cloud), benefits hyperscalers at expense of both VMware long-term and Rackspace. DISTRIBUTION: Rackspace absorbs margin destruction ($30-105M annually), customers absorb price increases or migration costs ($90-150M over 3 years), VMware/Broadcom CAPTURES all value ($100-210M annually) = total value extraction/destruction $220-465M over 3 years ($73-155M annually) with 100% capture by Broadcom, 0% retained by Rackspace or customers. ZERO-SUM or NEGATIVE-SUM outcome - value transferred from Rackspace and customers to Broadcom, no value created.
platform_rent_extraction.long_term_effect: PRIVATE CLOUD SEGMENT DESTRUCTION as both direct consequence and collateral damage. VMware rent extraction creates: (1) IMMEDIATE MARGIN COLLAPSE - Private Cloud segment becomes LOW-MARGIN or UNPROFITABLE (0-3% or negative EBITDA), cannot sustain operations at these economics, segment enters HARVEST MODE (extract cash, minimize investment, manage decline), (2) ACCELERATED CUSTOMER CHURN - VMware pricing triggers customer decision to EXIT Private Cloud entirely (migrate to Public Cloud or hyperscaler-direct) vs absorb increases, Stage 3.3 estimates 30-50% of VMware base at risk over 3-5 years = $90-150M revenue loss, (3) STRANDED INFRASTRUCTURE - Rackspace has SUNK INVESTMENT in Private Cloud data centers, hardware, expertise that becomes STRANDED ASSETS as customer base shrinks, cannot reduce costs proportionally with revenue (fixed infrastructure costs spread over declining base = margin compression accelerates), (4) STRATEGIC REPOSITIONING FAILURE - Rackspace attempting to pivot FROM Private Cloud (declining, high-cost, low-margin) TO Public Cloud and Government (growth areas), VMware extraction ACCELERATES Private Cloud decline faster than Rackspace can execute pivot, creates CASH FLOW CRISIS (losing $90-150M Private Cloud revenue = 6-11% of company revenue over 3 years, cannot replace quickly enough with Public Cloud growth given competitive dynamics). ENDPOINT: Private Cloud segment declines from $486M (2024) to $300-400M (2027-2028) as VMware-driven churn materializes = -20% to -38% cumulative revenue loss, segment margins remain compressed at 0-3%, segment becomes VALUE TRAP (large revenue nominal but generates minimal profit, consumes management attention and capital without returns). VMware/Broadcom rent extraction DESTROYS one of Rackspace's three major segments (Private Cloud 35% of revenue), contributing to company-wide terminal decline. IRONY: Broadcom extraction HELPS HYPERSCALERS (customers leaving VMware Private Cloud migrate to AWS/Azure Public Cloud, not to competitor MSPs) = VMware rent extraction benefits hyperscalers indirectly.
platform_rent_extraction.claim_type: FACT (VMware 200-300% increase, $100-210M impact) and INFERENCE (absorption distribution, long-term effects)
evidence_sources: Stage 2.5: VMware/Broadcom 200-300% price increase, $100-210M annual impact to Rackspace documented as fact
Stage 3.4: VMware cost absorption analysis estimating $30-105M (30-50%) absorbed by Rackspace
Stage 3.3: $90-150M Private Cloud VMware-based revenue at latent churn risk from pricing shock
Stage 2.1: Private Cloud revenue declining 13% YoY ($558M to $486M = -$72M)
Stage 2.4: Private Cloud switching costs $2-10M, 12-24 months creating technical lock-in that Broadcom exploits

platform_rent_extraction.platform_or_intermediary: Hyperscaler Marketplaces - Transaction fees and data extraction
platform_rent_extraction.rent_extraction_mechanism: MULTI-LAYER EXTRACTION through marketplace platform control. Mechanism: (1) TRANSACTION FEES - Hyperscaler marketplaces charge 3-7% of transaction value for listing, transaction processing, billing, and collection services (AWS Marketplace, Azure Marketplace public fee structures), Rackspace must pay to access customers procuring through marketplace channel, (2) CUSTOMER DATA HARVESTING - Marketplace transactions provide hyperscalers with granular customer intelligence (which Rackspace customers, deal sizes, pricing, consumption patterns, renewal dates, workload types), data used for COMPETITIVE TARGETING (hyperscaler account teams can identify high-value Rackspace customers and time competitive approaches to renewal cycles), (3) PROCUREMENT LOCK-IN - Enterprise customers adopting marketplace procurement for cloud spend consolidation, committed spend utilization, and procurement streamlining become LOCKED IN to marketplace channel (integrated with ERP, budgeting, reporting systems), creates MANDATORY CHANNEL for Rackspace to reach these customers, (4) ALGORITHMIC CONTROL - Hyperscalers control search rankings, recommendations, and visibility within marketplace, can promote own services (AWS Managed Services) or preferred partners above Rackspace in customer discovery, (5) ISV ECOSYSTEM FORCING - Software vendors require marketplace transactions for integrations, support, and credits, Stage 3.3 identifies marketplace/ISV requirements as churn trigger forcing customers to establish direct hyperscaler relationships (purchase ISV through marketplace, subsequently consolidate managed services). Extraction is COMPOUND: Direct fees (3-7%) PLUS competitive intelligence enabling customer targeting (value extraction through subsequent disintermediation) PLUS customer behavior shaping (marketplace habituates customers to hyperscaler relationship, reduces Rackspace differentiation).
platform_rent_extraction.who_absorbs_cost: RACKSPACE absorbs direct transaction costs, CUSTOMERS pay through reduced service quality or increased base pricing. (1) TRANSACTION FEES: If Rackspace processes $100-200M annually through marketplaces (estimated 15-30% of $690M Public Cloud, growing), 3-7% fees = $3-14M annually DIRECTLY absorbed by Rackspace (cannot add marketplace surcharge to customers, fees reduce Rackspace's margin). On estimated 3-5% Public Cloud segment EBITDA, $3-14M fees eliminate 20-100%+ of segment profit on marketplace transactions (makes marketplace business unprofitable or break-even). (2) COMPETITIVE DISPLACEMENT COSTS: Marketplace data enables hyperscaler targeting worth far more than transaction fees - if hyperscalers convert 10-20% of marketplace customers to direct managed services over 3-5 years (reasonable given Stage 3.3 $40-110M targeting estimate), marketplace becomes CUSTOMER LOSS CHANNEL not customer acquisition channel, Rackspace pays fees for privilege of providing customer data to competitors. (3) CUSTOMER OPPORTUNITY COST: Customers suffer through reduced Rackspace investment (fees compress margins, Rackspace cannot invest in service enhancements, product development, support quality), OR through BASE PRICING increases attempting to recover marketplace fees (but Stage 3.4 shows pricing increases trigger churn). Either way customers receive LESS VALUE (lower quality or higher prices) due to marketplace extraction. (4) ECOSYSTEM OPPORTUNITY COST: Marketplace fees are RENT for access to customer procurement channel that didn't exist historically (customers purchased directly from Rackspace website/sales), hyperscalers created TOLLBOOTH on customer access, extract fee without adding value (marketplace is convenience for hyperscalers to control transactions, not improvement for Rackspace).
platform_rent_extraction.long_term_effect: MARKETPLACE DEPENDENCY RATCHET creating DECLINING MARGINS and CUSTOMER LOSS CHANNEL. Long-term trajectory: Currently 15-30% of Public Cloud customers procure through marketplace (estimate), growing to 50-70% by 2027-2028 as enterprise marketplace adoption accelerates (industry trend: procurement consolidation, committed spend utilization, CFO-driven standardization). Each year more customers REQUIRE marketplace: (1) MARGIN COMPRESSION accelerates as larger share of revenue incurs 3-7% fees (Public Cloud segment margins decline from estimated 3-5% EBITDA toward 0-2% as marketplace penetration grows), (2) COMPETITIVE INTELLIGENCE accumulates (hyperscalers build complete visibility into Rackspace customer base, pricing, behaviors over time, enabling SYSTEMATIC targeting not opportunistic), (3) CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIPS SHIFT (customers view hyperscaler as PRIMARY relationship since billing, procurement, and infrastructure all hyperscaler-controlled, Rackspace becomes SECONDARY/TERTIARY), (4) DISINTERMEDIATION ACCELERATES (marketplace habituates customers to direct hyperscaler relationship, makes switching from Rackspace managed services to hyperscaler-direct managed services EASIER = behavioral barrier removed). ENDPOINT: Marketplace becomes DOMINANT procurement channel (60-80% of enterprise cloud services by 2028-2030), Rackspace faces: (A) PARTICIPATE and accept 3-7% fee + competitive intelligence sharing + customer relationship dilution, margins compressed to break-even, OR (B) REFUSE marketplace participation and lose access to 60-80% of enterprise customer procurement (automatic 60-80% revenue decline). NO VIABLE THIRD OPTION exists (cannot create competing marketplace, customers are on hyperscaler platforms, marketplace is extension of platform control). OUTCOME: Marketplace dependency converts from OPTIONAL (current: nice-to-have channel) to MANDATORY (future: required for enterprise access) while simultaneously becoming UNPROFITABLE (fees + competitive exposure) = Rackspace MUST participate in channel that destroys margins and feeds customers to hyperscaler competitors. STRATEGIC TRAP: Marketplace is HYPERSCALER-CONTROLLED CUSTOMER ACQUISITION FUNNEL that Rackspace pays to access, but funnel ultimately directs customers to hyperscaler-direct not to Rackspace (customers enter through marketplace, familiarize with hyperscaler platform, eventually consolidate to hyperscaler-direct).
evidence_sources: Stage 3.1: AWS Marketplace 50%+ annual growth documented as industry trend indicating channel importance increasing
Stage 3.3: Marketplace/ISV requirements identified as churn trigger forcing direct hyperscaler relationship establishment
Stage 3.2: Hyperscaler platforms control ecosystem including marketplace distribution channels
Industry pattern: Hyperscaler marketplace transaction fees typically 3-7% (AWS, Azure, Google public documentation)
Industry pattern: Enterprise marketplace adoption accelerating 2023-2028 as procurement consolidation trend

platform_rent_extraction.platform_or_intermediary: FedRAMP and compliance bodies - Certification cost inflation without competitive protection
platform_rent_extraction.rent_extraction_mechanism: MANDATORY CERTIFICATION COSTS with CONTINUOUS ESCALATION. Mechanism: FedRAMP and similar compliance frameworks extract value through: (1) INITIAL AUTHORIZATION COSTS - $2-5M for FedRAMP initial authorization (third-party assessors, documentation, infrastructure hardening, security controls implementation, government review), (2) ANNUAL MAINTENANCE COSTS - $500K-1M annually for FedRAMP continuous monitoring, audits, documentation updates, security testing (Stage 3.4: continuous monitoring requirements added 40-60% to ongoing costs), (3) UK SOVEREIGN INVESTMENT - $5-15M for UK government security standards compliance (Stage 2.5), separate from FedRAMP, cannot reuse certification, (4) CERTIFICATION MULTIPLICATION - Each regulatory framework requires separate certification (FedRAMP for US federal, StateRAMP for US state/local, UK standards for UK government, ISO for commercial, SOC 2 for customers, industry-specific like HIPAA, PCI-DSS), costs MULTIPLY (estimate: 5-8 major certifications × $500K-2M each = $2.5-16M total initial + $500K-1M annual each = $2.5-8M total ongoing), (5) REQUIREMENT INTENSIFICATION - Compliance standards tighten over time (cybersecurity threats evolve, government risk tolerance decreases, audit rigor increases), Stage 3.4 estimates compliance costs increased 30-50% over 2018-2025 = 5-8% CAGR, trend continues (estimate: 5-10% annual compliance cost inflation ongoing). Extraction mechanism is RENT-SEEKING: Compliance bodies (government agencies, industry standards organizations, third-party assessors) capture value by creating/enforcing requirements that providers must meet for market access, but compliance does NOT create competitive advantage (Stage 3.2: ~100 FedRAMP providers exist, many competitors authorized, certification is TABLE STAKES not differentiator). Providers PAY RENT (certification costs) for PERMISSION TO COMPETE (market access) without gaining PROTECTION FROM COMPETITION (authorized competitors numerous).
platform_rent_extraction.who_absorbs_cost: RACKSPACE absorbs compliance costs ENTIRELY, cannot pass through to government customers. Why absorption: (1) GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT PRICING - Government agencies expect competitive pricing (often LOWER than commercial due to volume, multi-year commitments, budget constraints), will not pay premiums for compliance (view as provider obligation, not value-add service), (2) COMPETITIVE PRESSURE - Stage 3.2 documents ~100 FedRAMP providers including AWS GovCloud and Azure Government, customers have AUTHORIZED alternatives with LOWER or COMPARABLE pricing (hyperscalers amortize compliance costs over $10B+ government revenues, can offer better price-performance), Rackspace cannot increase prices to recover compliance costs without losing competitive procurement bids, (3) CONTRACT STRUCTURES - Government contracts often have PRICE PROTECTION clauses (price ceilings, most favored customer pricing, economic price adjustments limited) preventing mid-contract price increases to recover escalating compliance costs, (4) MARGIN TOLERANCE - Government segment estimated 0-3% EBITDA margins (Stage 3.4), any attempt to increase pricing would make Rackspace UNCOMPETITIVE (competitors operating at similar low margins, price increases lose bids), must absorb compliance costs to remain viable. Result: $5-10M annual compliance costs absorbed FULLY by Rackspace = 4-8% of $127M Government segment revenue consumed by compliance burden = PRIMARY reason Government segment has LOWEST margins in company portfolio (high cost-to-serve without corresponding pricing power).
platform_rent_extraction.long_term_effect: GOVERNMENT SEGMENT MARGIN TRAP with ESCALATING COSTS and INTENSIFYING COMPETITION. Long-term effects: (1) CONTINUOUS MARGIN COMPRESSION - Compliance costs increasing 5-10% annually while Government pricing flat or declining (budget pressures, competitive procurement), margin compression ACCELERATES (estimated 0-3% EBITDA currently declining toward NEGATIVE 2-5% by 2027-2028 if trend continues without restructuring), (2) STRANDED INVESTMENT - $10-25M cumulative invested in FedRAMP, UK Sovereign, and other certifications creates SUNK COST TRAP (Rackspace cannot exit Government segment without writing off investments, must continue serving low/negative-margin segment), (3) COMPETITIVE DISADVANTAGE - AWS UK Sovereign launch 2025-2026 provides government customers with HYPERSCALER-NATIVE compliant alternative with superior capabilities at comparable or lower pricing, Rackspace's compliance investments provide ZERO protection (AWS also compliant, customers prefer AWS platform breadth), Stage 3.3 estimates $50-75M Government revenue at risk, (4) WORKING CAPITAL BURDEN - Compliance costs must be paid UPFRONT (authorizations, audits, certifications require payment before market access granted), revenue earned OVER TIME (government contracts are multi-year), creates NEGATIVE CASH FLOW cycle (invest $5-15M initially, earn back over 3-5 years at low margins), ties up capital in low-return segment. ENDPOINT: Government segment becomes PROFITLESS REVENUE (appears as $127M in top-line but generates zero or negative profit) requiring subsidization from Private Cloud and Public Cloud segments. As those segments also deteriorate (VMware extraction destroying Private Cloud per above, hyperscaler extraction destroying Public Cloud per above), company CANNOT SUSTAIN subsidy of Government segment. Path to resolution: (1) EXIT Government segment entirely (write off $10-25M sunk costs, lose $127M revenue, focus resources on more profitable segments) - but NO profitable segments exist after intermediary extraction, OR (2) RESTRUCTURE Government business to bare-minimum (reduce compliance costs by exiting some frameworks, accept revenue loss, minimize losses) - but reduces addressable market further. OUTCOME: Compliance rent extraction creates STRATEGIC BURDEN (low-margin segment consuming resources) that Rackspace cannot exit (sunk costs) and cannot fix (no pricing power, escalating costs, intensifying competition). Government segment is DISTRACTION from core business challenges (Private/Public Cloud deterioration) while CONTRIBUTING to overall financial weakness.
platform_rent_extraction.claim_type: INFERENCE with FACT-based components (compliance cost estimates)
evidence_sources: Stage 3.4: Compliance cost escalation documented, 30-50% increase 2018-2025, 40-60% from continuous monitoring
Stage 2.5: UK Sovereign investment $5-15M documented as fact
Stage 3.2: ~100 FedRAMP providers documented, indicates compliance doesn't create competitive moat
Stage 3.3: $50-75M Government revenue at risk from hyperscaler compliance alternatives
Stage 1.5: Government segment $127M revenue (9% of total)
Industry estimates: FedRAMP $2-5M initial, $500K-1M annual maintenance (government and industry sources)
